ygData.subject: Fitness Function
ygData.msgSnippet: I am testing NEAT against the problem of detecting fraud.  My approach is different than many of the examples because it is not a robot/game approach where you

I am testing NEAT against the problem of detecting fraud.  My approach is d=
ifferent than many of the examples because it is not a robot/game approach =
where you know the state at any given time and it is definative.  With frau=
d, it is shades of gray.

The other thing is I am using a set of data to tr=
ain on.  I have 10,000 cases, and test each genome against 8,000 cases.  2,=
000 cases are being held out for independent validation.

So my question is=
 on the fitness function.  Here is my current approach.  Basically I am sum=
ming the squared error for all 8,000 cases that I run through the genome:
f=
oreach (DataRow dr in dtTrain.Rows)
{
    SetInputs(dr);
    box.Activate()=
;
    double out1 =3D box.OutputSignalArray[0];
    double err;
    if (isF=
raud =3D=3D 1)
        err =3D 1 - out1;
    else
        err =3D out1;
   =
 err *=3D err; // square the error
    fitness +=3D 100 - (int)Math.Round(1=
00 * err, 0);
}

Now, since I test a genome on a set of cases instead of a =
single state, I am wondering if the sum of the error is the best approach i=
n my case.  Obviously, STDEV comes to mind as one other possibility.

My cu=
rrent approach seems to have problems complexing.  After 5,000 generations =
(population 500), the best genome is quite simplistic.  My fitness has also=
 only gone from 512,486 to 514,743.  This translates into getting 1001 of t=
he 2,000 test cases correct (so basically just coin flip results).  My old =
neural net gets 1200 correct so it isn't my inputs (ok, maybe data conditio=
ning is an issue?).  For data conditioning, I am using 0 centered StdDev =
=3D 1.

The connections for the best genome is below. Nodes 0-75 are inputs=
 (my current neural network trained via other techniques uses 60 of those i=
nputs and is 60% accurate).  Node 76 is the output, and any id above 76 is =
a hidden node.
    
    <Connections>
      <Con id=3D"147" src=3D"145" tgt=
=3D"76" wght=3D"0.11515210787375874" /> 
      <Con id=3D"184" src=3D"182" =
tgt=3D"76" wght=3D"-0.15767564282512914" /> 
      <Con id=3D"293" src=3D"6=
2" tgt=3D"145" wght=3D"-7.6662831469826536" /> 
      <Con id=3D"589" src=
=3D"145" tgt=3D"182" wght=3D"-10" /> 
      <Con id=3D"763" src=3D"47" tgt=
=3D"182" wght=3D"-8.1612453869437189" /> 
      <Con id=3D"2140" src=3D"1" =
tgt=3D"2139" wght=3D"9.95966789207033" /> 
      <Con id=3D"2141" src=3D"21=
39" tgt=3D"182" wght=3D"9.9724126338387382" /> 
    </Connections>

As you =
may have deduced from my connections, I use a weight range of 10.  I starte=
d out using the default 5, but it quickly started producing multiple hidden=
 nodes that did nothing but connect to one another in order to accumulate a=
 total weight > 5.  Maybe this is desired in NEAT to increase complexity?

=
So any advise would be greatly appreciated.  My current area of focus is th=
e fitness function approach and the weight setting.  Of course, comments/su=
ggestions on other areas would also be apprecitated.
